metadata.title: In situ mechanical characterization of CoCrCuFeNi high-entropy alloy micro/nano-pillars for their size-dependent mechanical behavior

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Traditionally, alloy is based on one or two principal elements withminor addition of alloying elements added to improve its properties, forming an alloy family based on the principal element [1]. High-entropy alloys (HEAs), roughly defined as a solid solution containsmultiple-elements at an equimolar or near-equimolar ratios [2, 3], have aroused increasing attentions not only for their ability to form single crystalline structure, but also due to their unique physical andmechanical properties that attributed to the extremely high configuration entropy like the excellent specific strength, superiormechanical performance at high temperatures, exceptional ductility and fracture toughness at cryogenic temperatures, superparamagnetism, and superconductivity, etc [4–8]. Up to date,most previousworks of theHEAs aremainly confined onmacroscale [9–12], like the hardness [13], wearresistance [14], strength-to-weight ratio [15], while themechanical response atmicro- or nano-scale are still rarely investigated.With the query of what’s the strength, ductility and size-dependency that single-crystalline HEAs presents atmicron and nano-scales when comparingwith their bulk counterparts, studies on themicromechanical responses ofHEAswere emerged out by applying themicrocompression technique [16] to ionmilledmicro-/nano-pillars. First study about themicromechanical properties ofHEAswas on the Al80.8CoCrCuFeNimicro-pillars for the purpose of comparing themechanical response differences between the dendritic and interdendritic region, and it was found that the bcc-phase-containing region has a remarkably higher yield strength than the pure-fcc-phase-containing region [17]. Ex situmicro-/nano-compression tests was conducted on a BCC-structuredNb25Mo25Ta25W25HEAmicro- and nano-pillars with different sizes ranged from200–2000 nm to study the size effect on themechanical properties, which found that BCC-
© 2016 IOPPublishing Ltd
structuredHEApillars exhibited higher strength levels than their pure element counterparts, togetherwith a relatively lower strength size dependency [18]. Interestingly, a recent work done by the same group based on this Nb25Mo25Ta25W25HEA revealed an extraordinarily high yield strengthwhen the single crystalmicro-/nanopillars becoming nanocrystals, togetherwith an even lower size dependency [19]. Furthermore, the specific strengthening and tougheningmechanismof theHEAswere systematically studied onCrMnFeCoNiHEAby an in situTEMmanner [20]. Among those pioneeringHEAmicro-/nano-mechanical characterizationworks, the size-dependentmechanical properties of a commonly used, typical FCC-structuredCoCrCuFeNiHEA are less studied. In this work, themicro-/nano-mechanical responses of the CoCrCuFeNiHEAmicro/nanopillars were quantitatively investigated by an in situ compression testing platformbased on a high-resolution nanoindenter inside SEM. The size effect on the yield stress ofHEAmicro-/nano-pillars with diameters ranged from 500–2000 nmwas studied. Their corresponding Young’smoduli and plastic deformationmechanismswere also discussed.Ourwork could be useful for FCC-structuredHEA’s applications inmicro- and nanoscale devices/ components [4, 13].

sections.heading: 2.1. Sample preparation and characterizations
sections.text:
Multi-component CoCrCuFeNi alloy [4, 17] ingots were prepared by arc-meltingmixtures of puremetals (with purity of about 99.9 at.%) in a Ti-gettered high-purity argon atmosphere [2, 21]. Each ingotwasmelted at least five times in the arcmelter in order to obtain chemical homogeneity. Eventually, theCoCrCuFeNiHEAwere synthesized viamelting and suction casting into a rectangular coppermoldwith dimensions of ∼30×10×10 mm.The bulk samples were thenmechanically polishedwith silicon carbide paper, diamond paste down to 1 μmbymanual operation and autopolishingmachine down to 0.5 μm, before finallymachined down to themicro-/nano-sized pillar samples.
Themicrostructural and composition characterizations on the synthesizedHEAbulk samplewere firstly carried by a SEMequippedwith EDX and EBSD, as shown infigure 1(a). Electron backscattered diffraction (EBSD) characterization togetherwith the inverse polemap indicated the grains aremainly 〈100〉 and 〈120〉 oriented, (figure 1(b)). Allmicro-/nano-pillars were selectively fabricated by the ion-millingmethod from the grainwith 〈100〉 orientationwith a tapering angle of 2–3° (figure 1(c)). The 〈100〉 crystal orientation of the fabricatedmicro-/nano-pillars was further characterized by a high resolution TEM (as shown infigure 1(d), togetherwith Selected Area ElectronDiffraction (SAED) analysis inserted). TheHRTEM image also confirms theHEAhas a typical FCC-structure with a lattice parameter of∼3.54 Å, as calculated from the inter-planar distance of (200)planes (1.77 Å). STEM-EDX elementarymapping characterization shows the atomic scale mixing of all thefive principlemetal elements (Co, Cr, Cu, Fe,Ni) in theHEA sample, as presented infigures S1(a)–(f) (supplementary information), which is comparable to the previously reported bulk CoCrCuFeNi HEAs [13].
2.2. In situ SEMmicro/nanocompression In situ compression tests of the as-fabricatedmicro/nanopillars were performed on a quantitative picoindentor (Hysitron™PI85) system equippedwith diamond conicalflat punch tips (1 μmand 5 μmin diameter for different samples, Synton-MDP, Switzerland) inside SEM (FEI™Quanta FEG 450), as shown infigures 1(e) and (f). To quantify the size effect inmechanical property of the CoCrCuFeNiHEAmicro-/nanostructure, pillars with diameters ranged from500 to 2000 nmwere prepared by the ion-millingmethod using a RAITH ionLINE ion beam lithography systembased on the bulk samples. A two-stepmillingmethodwas employed: 2.5 nA for coarsemilling and 10–40 pA for finemilling. There are totally 3 characteristic sizedmicro/nanopillars were fabricated (in∼500 nm,∼1000 nmand∼2000 nm for pillar diameters)with aspect ratios of∼2.5–5.5. A taper of ∼3–4 degrees was generally observed in theHEAmicro/nanopillars on the bulk substrate, andwill be corrected when calculating their Young’smoduli. All tests were performed under the displacement control [16]mode in a uniaxial, quasi-static compressionmode [22]. Sample alignment was always checked to ensure the nanoindenter head and themicro-/nano-pillars werewell aligned for uniaxial compression tests, as shown in figure S2 (supplementary information). Typical results of samples from each size/diameter domainwere selected out and converted into stress-strain curves for further analysis refers to Young’smodulus, yield strengths aswell as the quantitative deformation properties.

sections.heading: 3. Results
sections.text:
Wefirstly show the deformation behaviour of samples under uniaxial compression tests and their corresponding yield strengths as a function of sample diameters (the∼500 nm,∼1000 nm, and∼2000 nm
groups), as shown infigures 2(a)–(j): For the∼500 nmnanopillars with a tapering angle∼4° and aspect ratio∼3, the original nanopillar before compressionwas intrinsic and smoothwithout observed flawor contamination on the surface, as shown infigure 2(a). The deformation behaviour featured a typicalmetallic-like elastic-plastic property with obvious slip-bands (figure 2(b)) on the nanopillar bodies when yielding, the calculated yield strength is∼740MPa at a strain value of 0.013, as presented in the stress versus strain plot infigure 2(c). Similar deformation behaviour upon yieldingwere observed on the 1 μmand 2 μmmicro-pillars, as shown in figures 2(d)–(e) (tapering angle∼3° and aspect ratio∼3) andfigures 2(g)–(h) (tapering angle∼3°, aspect ratio ∼2.5), respectively. As presented in the stress versus strain plots infigures 2(f) and (i), the corresponding yield strengths and strains for the two different sizemicropillars are∼520MPa at∼0.011 and∼450MPa at∼0.012, respectively (note that, all the stress-strain curves after yielding are not shown, due to the complicated stress/ strain conversion for plastically deformed sample geometries). To summarize the size effect on theHEAmicro/ nanopillars, typical results of each size/diameter domainwere picked out for the studying of the strength
Figure 1. Sample characterizations and experimental configuration: (a), SEM image of CoCrCuFeNiHEA in bulk status; (b), corresponding EBSD analysis of theHEAbulk sample in (a), the inserted inverse polemap shows that the crystalline orientation of the green grains is [100]; (c), a typical ion-milled nano-pillar from the [100] grain before indentation; (d), HRTEManalysis on theHEA nanopillar in (c) from the axial direction, combingwith the inserted SAEDpattern, we can further confirm that the axial orientation of the nanopillar is [100]; (e), over view of the high resolution nanoindenter based in situmicro-/nano-pillar compression system, the zoom in of the red frame in (f) shows the good alignment between the indenter head and the nanopillar.
responses to the changing of diameters. The corresponding ln(σmax) to the ln (D) relationship plot togetherwith thefitted curvewas listed infigure 2(j). Them value in theσ∝D−m relationshipwas fitted as 0.462, whichwas lower than the typical value of 0.6–0.9 for FCCmetals in thewell-knownHall-Petch relationship [23–25]. By comparing the results from this work and literatures data [26] on the bulkHEA,we found that theCoCrCuFeNi HEAmicro/nanopillars still show the size effect (i.e. stronger than their bulk counterpart) but appeared to be less sensitive in terms of their yield strengths.
To further quantify the elastic behaviour andYoung’smoduli ofHEAmicro/nanopillars, uniaxial loadingunloading compression experiments with increased peak displacements was applied, as one typical case shown infigure 3. Infigure 3(a), after experiencing an uniaxial compression strain of∼0.0085, theHEAnanopillar (tapering angle∼3°, aspect ratio∼5.5) could still recover to its original length upon unloading, with little evidence of plastic deformation, andwithout any observable bending/buckling. After that, another loadingunloading runwas also performedwith strain up to∼0.013, as shown infigure 3(b), which indicated that the elastic deformation range of this particularHEAnanopillar (with diameter∼500 nm) is up to 0.013. Eventually, the plastic deformation visibly started at∼0.015 strainwhichwas featured by the onset offirst slip band together with the non-linear changes on the stress versus strain curve, as shown infigures 3(c) and (d), the yield stress is ∼614.4 MPa. Based on the stress versus strain curve of the elastic deformation case listed infigure 3(b), the apparent elasticmodulus was estimated to be∼45 GPa (strain:∼0.013, stress:∼584.2 MPa). However, considering the combined effects of pillar tapering angle, aspect ratio and substrate compliance, we performed corrections on themeasured apparentmodulus by following the reference [27], and the Young’smodulus of the HEAwas corrected to be∼70 GPa for this particular samples (D∼500 nm). Similarly, we obtained the Young’s moduli for the samples with different diameters (as seen infigure 2), ranging from56.5–82.5 GPa, which are reasonably close to the reported values for the bulkHEAwith similar compositions (such as [17]) but slightly smaller (considering that the Young’smoduli of nanostructuredmaterials could be slightly lower than their bulk counterparts in general due to size effect [28, 29]). In addition, despite being a single crystal, a recent study shows that thisHEA (CoCrCuFeNi) could have two separated phases at the same time, with one phase having higher Cu composition than the other, thus a slightly lower Young’smodulus could be expected in the pillar samples etched from theCu rich phase [30].

Figure 2. Yield strengths for the threemicro-/nano-pillarswith different diameters and the corresponding size dependency: (a), a nanopillar with diameter of 500 nmbefore compression; (b), themorphology changes of the nanopillar at the occasion of yielding (with an obvious slip initiated near the top of the nanopillar); (c), corresponding stress versus strain plot of the 500 nmnanopillar until yielding, showing the yield strength of the nanopillar is∼720 MPa at the strain of∼0.013. (d), amicro-pillar with diameter of 1 μm before compression; (e), themorphology of the pillar at the occasion of yielding (with a slip occurred at themiddle part of themicropillar). (f), corresponding stress versus strain plot of the 1 μmmicro-pillar until yield, showing the yield strength of∼520 MPa at the strain of∼0.011. (g), amicro-pillar with diameter of 2 μmbefore compression; (h), themorphology of themicro-/nano-pillar at the occasion of yielding (showing a slip generated at the bottompart of themicro-pillar). (i), corresponding stress versus strain plot of the 2 μmmicro-pillar until yielding, showing the yield strength of∼450 MPa at the strain of∼0.012. (j), the relationship between the ln(σmax) and ln(D), inwhich theσmaxmeans the yield stress, andDmeans the diameter of themicro-/nano-pillars. The slope of the fitted red curve gives them value in theσ toD−m relationship as 0.462, showing the size dependency in yield strength.
4.Discussion
For conventional alloys, the deformationmechanism ismainly dictated by the dislocations slip [31] and deformation twinning [32]; while for amorphous alloys, the deformationmechanisms aremainly based on two classicalmodels: Shear-transition-zone byArgon and Free volume by Spaepen [33]. ForHEA, due to that they have quite uniform single crystalline lattice structures (as shown inHRTEM images offigure 1(d)) butwith differentmetal elements, their plastic-deformationmechanism is believed to be between the conventional alloys and the amorphousmetals [4]. A recent in situmechanical testingwork [20] revealed an intrinsic and extrinsic synergy tougheningmechanism onCrMnFeCoNiHEA, inwhich they found that theHEAwas intrinsically toughened bymultiple deformationmechanisms at different deformation stages, like the easymotion of Shockley partial dislocations and the forming of stacking-fault parallelepipeds, the arrest of undissociated dislocations at planar slip bands. In this work, the plastic deformation process appeared quite similar with that of conventionalmetals/alloys, as presented infigures 4 and 5 of two typical plastic deformation cases.
In the case offigure 4, the single crystallinemicro-pillar was deformed based on the traditional crystalline plane slipping system. Aftermeasuring the included angle between the slipped planes and the axis direction of themicro-pillar, as shown infigure 4(a), we believe that themiller index of the slipped crystalline plane is (111), given that the included angle between them is∼55°, which quite near the theoretical value of 54.73° between (100) and (111) for typical FCCdislocation slips. From this result we believe that the plastic deformation of the FCC-structureHEAmicro/nanopillars still prefers the close-packed crystalline plane, and following the typical 〈110〉{111} FCC-structure slipping system. The slipping process was presented by the extracted video frames that listed infigures 4(b)–(e), which roughly presented the slip bands’ generation process upon compressing. Beside the uniform single slipping deformation process, amultiple slipping behaviourwas also observed on anothermicro-pillar, as shown infigure 5. Aftermeasuring of the incline angles of these two sets of different slipped planes, as shown infigure 5(a), we found that their incline angles are also all∼55°. The deformation process was listed infigures 5(b)–(j), which represented the generation process of the slip planes. Similar with the previous case listed infigure 4(a), it can be found that the plastic deformation of the FCC-structureHEAmicro/
Figure 3. Elastic deformation behavior andYoung’smodulus analysis of aHEAmicro-pillar: loading-unloading compression tests on theHEAmicro-pillar, during thefirst three loading cycles the sample can always recover to its original length upon unloading, whichmeans the deformationwas elastic. (a) shows the 2nd loading-unloading process, with the corresponding stress versus strain plot listed in (d), for which the calculated elastic strain is∼0.008; (b) shows the 3rd loading-unloading runwith full recovery, with the corresponding stress versus strain plots shown in (d), showing an elastic strain of∼0.013; (c) shows thefinal run until the sample came into the plastic deformation regime, with the corresponding stress versus strain plots was shown in (d), fromwhich the yield strength was determined to be∼614 MPa at the strain of∼0.015. (d), stress versus strain plots of the loading-unloading tests for calculating the Young’smodulus of theHEA sample.
Figure 4. Plastic deformation behavior and slip systemanalysis for amicro-pillar with single slip system: (a), post-mortem analysis of a typicalHEAmicro-pillar after considerable plastic deformation. The included angle between the slip plane and themicropillar axis ismeasured as∼55°, similar to the included angle between the (100) and (111) crystalline planes. Togetherwith the [100] orientation of themicro-pillar, the slipped planewas inferred as (111)plane and the slipping system is the typical 〈110〉{111}. (b), the original status of thismicro-pillar before compression. (c), origin offirst slip band; d,more slipping occurred based on the same slipping system. (e),final status of themicro-pillar upon further compressing.
Figure 5. Plastic deformation behavior and slip systemanalysis for amicro-pillar withmultiple slip system: (a), post-mortem analysis of a typicalHEAmicro-pillar after considerable plastic deformation. The included angles between themicro-pillar axis and those two sets of slipped are allmeasured as∼55°, whichmeans those planes belongs to the same crystalline plane family but with differentmiller indices. Use the same principle applied in the case of figure 4, the slipped planeswere inferred as belonging to the {111} crystalline plane family and the slipping system is the typical 〈110〉{111}. (b), the original status of thismicro-pillar before compression. (c), origin offirst slip band; (d), multiple slipping occurred based on the same slipping system. (e), a new slip band generated in a different slipping direction. (f)–(i), developing of slip bandswith the increasing of compression depth. (j),final status of the sample upon further compressing.
nanopillars still follow the traditionalmetal crystalline plane slippingmechanism,with the typical 〈110〉{111} FCC-structure slipping systemhere. Therefore, themechanisms for theHEA size insensitive behaviour is believed to bemainly associatedwith hindered dislocationmobility in a distorted lattice (due tomultiple elements), which could significantly increase the lattice resistance inHEAmicro/nanostructures, thereby elevating the overall strength butmitigating its size dependence.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, themechanical behaviour of single crystalline CoCrCuFeNiHEA atmicro/nanoscales was quantitatively characterized by in situ SEMcompression tests. The ion-milledmicro/nano-pillar samples with uniform [100] crystal orientation and diameters of∼500 nm,∼1000 nmand∼2000 nmwere systematically studied and compared. Results show that the yield strengths ofHEAmicro/nano-pillars are size dependent (i.e. ‘smaller is stronger’), but less sensitive when comparedwith that of typical FCCmetals, with a relatively lowerm value (∼0.462) in thefittedσ∝D−mHall-Petch relationship plot, as compared to typical FCCmetal structures withm values ranging from∼0.6 to 0.9.We believe that the strengthening and the size-insensitivemechanical behaviour of theHEAmicro/nano-pillars are associatedwith unconventional dislocation dynamics and slip systems as well as the lattice resistance inHEA crystalline structure by localized distortion at atomic length scales. The quantitative understanding of themechanical responses ofHEA atmicro- and nanoscalesmay provide useful guidance for the design and fabrication ofHEA structural/functional components in themicro/nanodevices and instruments.

referenceMentions.context: High-entropy alloys (HEAs), roughly defined as a solid solution containsmultiple-elements at an equimolar or near-equimolar ratios [2, 3], have aroused increasing attentions not only for their ability to form single crystalline structure, but also due to their unique physical andmechanical properties that attributed to the extremely high configuration entropy like the excellent specific strength, superiormechanical performance at high temperatures, exceptional ductility and fracture toughness at cryogenic temperatures, superparamagnetism, and superconductivity, etc [4–8].

High-entropy alloys (HEAs), roughly defined as a solid solution containsmultiple-elements at an equimolar or near-equimolar ratios [2, 3], have aroused increasing attentions not only for their ability to form single crystalline structure, but also due to their unique physical andmechanical properties that attributed to the extremely high configuration entropy like the excellent specific strength, superiormechanical performance at high temperatures, exceptional ductility and fracture toughness at cryogenic temperatures, superparamagnetism, and superconductivity, etc [4–8].

Up to date,most previousworks of theHEAs aremainly confined onmacroscale [9–12], like the hardness [13], wearresistance [14], strength-to-weight ratio [15], while themechanical response atmicro- or nano-scale are still rarely investigated.

Furthermore, the specific strengthening and tougheningmechanismof theHEAswere systematically studied onCrMnFeCoNiHEAby an in situTEMmanner [20].
Ourwork could be useful for FCC-structuredHEA’s applications inmicro- and nanoscale devices/ components [4, 13].

In addition, despite being a single crystal, a recent study shows that thisHEA (CoCrCuFeNi) could have two separated phases at the same time, with one phase having higher Cu composition than the other, thus a slightly lower Young’smodulus could be expected in the pillar samples etched from theCu rich phase [30].

For conventional alloys, the deformationmechanism ismainly dictated by the dislocations slip [31] and deformation twinning [32]; while for amorphous alloys, the deformationmechanisms aremainly based on two classicalmodels: Shear-transition-zone byArgon and Free volume by Spaepen [33].

A recent in situmechanical testingwork [20] revealed an intrinsic and extrinsic synergy tougheningmechanism onCrMnFeCoNiHEA, inwhich they found that theHEAwas intrinsically toughened bymultiple deformationmechanisms at different deformation stages, like the easymotion of Shockley partial dislocations and the forming of stacking-fault parallelepipeds, the arrest of undissociated dislocations at planar slip bands.

metadata.abstractText: High entropy alloys (HEAs), as a new kind of alloys with equior near equi-atomic alloy compositions, have recently received increased interest, but theirmechanical properties atmicroand nanoscales are less studied, which could hinder their structural/functional applications in the small scales. In this work, themechanical responses of single crystalline FCC-structuredCoCrCuFeNiHEAmicroand nano-pillars were systematically investigated by an in situ SEMnanoindenter. The yield strengths of theHEAmicro-/nano-pillars under uniaxial compression appear to be size-dependent (with them value of∼0.46 in theHall-Petch law relationship), but less sensitive when compared to typicalmetal/ alloymicroand nano-structures (e.g. with them values of 0.6–0.9 for FCCmetals).We also observed and analyzed the slip systems of the plastically deformedmicro-/nano-pillars, and discussed their deformationmechanisms together with the Young’smodulus bymultiple loading/unloading compressions experiments. Our results could provide useful insights in the design and application of HEA for functionalmicroand nano-devices.
